newsitem.title: USA: Olympics gave Georgia a $4 bln boost - report.
newsitem.headline: Olympics gave Georgia a $4 bln boost - report.

text.p: The Olympics pumped $4 billion into the Georgia economy, and should give state and local governments a $400 million revenue boost, Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University said Thursday.
In his quarterly economic forecast, center director Donald Ratajczak predicted economic gains would slow as Olympics workers are absorbed into other parts of the workforce.

Atlanta's employment growth will slow from 91,300 new jobs in 1996 to 46,700 jobs in 1997, and then edge up to 51,600 jobs in 1998 amid weakness in the construction industry, the forecast said. Unemployment will rise from the curent very low 3.8 percent to 5.1 percent in 1998, the forecast said.

The statewide economy will also slow but the plunge in apparel employment is abating, Ratajczak said. Georgia employment should increase by 68,700 in 1997 and the state should have little trouble with revenue growth even as it trims two cents from the four cent sales tax on food in October, the forecast said.

But the subsequent penny per year reductions in 1997 and 1998 could cause budget problems as post-Olympics revenue growth slows to 5.5 percent in 1997 and an anemic 4.5 percent in 1998, the forecast said.
